 Do not look up the lyrics, that's cheating... and my job.

Glossolalia?

 
 
 Well, unfrortunatly since Jckker didn't respond I decided to look it up.
 
 Turns out it's Enya lyrics...
 
 ...and I'm 100% correct.
 It's made up ####, known as Glossolalia. aka 'speaking in tongues' for those in the Chrisitan charismatic community.
 
 In past research on 'tongues' over the past few years I came across the fact that some pagan types do it also as well as insane people. Some people (Enya and Dead Can Dance IIRC) even use it in music.
 Last year, a research group did brain scans on tongues speakers and found that the parts of the brain associated with speach were little effected but the parts associated with emotion received more blood flow.
 It has more in common with meditation and chanting than with actually speaking a language.
 
 For this particular song, it was used in the movie Gladiator starring Russell Crowe I found out.
 Phoenetically, some of the words sould latinish. And the only word present that is really a word is Shalom, Hebrew IIRC.
 This type of phenomina gives people the impression that it's a real language when it's nothing but gibberish.
 Mush like when tongues speakers in Chruch toss in 'Jesus' or someother Christo-babble word.
 
 And, while this isn't a religious thread, initially, those who started the recent phenomina of Glossolalia, Pentacostalism in the early 1900's really thought they were speaking a foreign language and not gibberish. Some even going so far in this belief as to travel to other countries...and speak in tongues at people there thinking they were spreading the word of God.
 Over the past decades, the Pentecostals have changed their beliefs on what Glossolalia was for them. Inventing the concept that there are 3 different types of gifts of tongues, one being Glossolalia that's gibberish (for praying to God) and another XenoGlossia, for speaking a new language they never knew before like Germans speaking English or Mandarin to spread the word.
 They really play loose with interpriting their bible.
 
 This brought to you by Zardoz.
 As I tell my wife, "I know everything about everything" (while an over exageration, I do play a mean game of trivial pursuit and know a decent amount on linguistics).
 
 
 Personally, I was hoping these lyrics would have been an actual language, like Deep Forest's 'Lulliby'.
 Something with actual meaning that would make me cry over it's message...rather than cry over there realisation that there really is no message. Unless you make one up.

I think this is hebrew

 
 
 *sigh*
 
 Did you even read the post above by me?
 
 I am 100 percent correct. As I said, I looked it up to confirm my beliefs.
 
 Shalom is the only word that would have any passing resemblance to Hebrew.
 ALL other words and MADE UP.
Is it the theme of the Elysian fields? I don't remember any Jewish storyline in Gladiator.

Is it the theme of the Elysian fields? I don't remember any Jewish storyline in Gladiator.

 
 The song was used for that during the movie.
 I think the song predates the movie.
 
 My wife likes Enya so had the CD.
 
 It's pretty sounding. But completly nonsense.
 Even the singer admitted that it was glossalalia.

And the only word present that is really a word is Shalom, Hebrew IIRC.
 

 
 
Shalom is the only word that would have any passing resemblance to Hebrew.
 ALL other words and MADE UP.

 
 You're wrong. 
 
 The word "flesh" is present. "Lof flesh lay"
 Is that a typo? I'm surprised you missed one of two English words in this song.
 
 Also present is "we", multiple times. "We de ze zu bu"
 We is a word if I'm not mistaken.
 
 There are also foreign words including: la, de, a (the, of, to)
 
 Also there is a hindi word in that song as well. "tum", which I believe is a way of saying "you". "Shaley koot-tum"
 
 
 See? You were wrong : )

Mmmm.... ham....

 
 More like Pie... emoticon_smile 
 
 
 Noises that sound like words are not words.
 What Aivlis is failing to understand is that the song lyrics presented in their given form are merely the writers best guess at the spoken word when trying to transcribe it.
 
 'We' may be a word to some, but on it's own is just a noise. More so considering the context it's presented in.
 Also, the artist may actually think of the correct spelling as 'Gnoiu'. With silent G and N. Which, isn't a word.
 
 [preacher mode]
 
 Now, get ready.
 Get ready.
 A miracle is going to happen now.
 
 When dealing with music, the syllables of a word are often stetched out. This is proven the case when you actually listen to the song.
 
 Thusly, sayeth Zardoz, We de ze zu bu
 Could actually be more like Wedezezubu.
 See what I'm sayin'?
 
 Okay, now turn to your neighbor and slap em. 
 Are you ready for your supernatural break through yet?
 
 'Course ya are.
 
 Now, when we look up Wedezezubu an the special golden tablets I've been given, we find that it's Cherubic for Chicken ####er. 
 Are you with me? Course you are.
 
 Now, when we look up Wedesoooaru which is actually Wede Soaru, we find that in Cherubic it's Chicken Plucker.
 
 Now, to answer your heart's question, 'Shaley koot-tum' is actually Shallhey Kootum which actually isn't Cherubic but a sub dialect of Seraphi for Goat Sodomy. It hasn't been used since the great heavenly conflict known as the War of Northern Angelic Agression. It was a dialect most used by the Southern Angelic Hosts and the current dialect is known as Gweeni Stefani and has been in use by the Gweeni hosts who were exiled to Lake Holtzell about 27,000 years ago.
 
 Now, you're empowered for your harvest of spiritual blessings.
 
 Turn to your neighbor and say 'I'm empowered to harvest my spiritual blessings!'
 
 Praise tha Lawrd!
 
 [/end preacher mode]
 
 
 See, one of the problems with Glossalalia is that most practioners use sounds that, while actually familiar, sound alienish to them. 
 Isn't it odd that ALL of Enya's music...sounds the same? Even the songs with real words sound similar to this made up stuff...because people use what's familiar.
 You'll find many still rolling their R's and using familiar cadences and tonal inflictions. But, ignoring any linguistic structuring as they go along. 
 Linguistics experts state that it's most closely related to the babbling an infant does. Mimmicking certain sounds with no real meaning or understanding.
 In a recent 2006 study, the parts of the brains affected by glossia aren't those used for languages but, IIRC, emotions.

I didn't read most of your post because it got really boring.
 
 
Noises that sound like words are not words.
 What Aivlis is failing to understand is that the song lyrics presented in their given form are merely the writers best guess at the spoken word when trying to transcribe it.

 
 So? What you are failing to understand is that the writer of the lyrics still wrote their interpretation of a sound the same way that some people who speak the English language write certain words. I can understand if it sounded like "we" or "flesh" but was written a different way but it is not. W + E = WE okay?
 
 It does not flippin' matter if We de ze zu bu is stretched out to SOUND like wedezebu#### or whatever. I'm talking about the written form. Often times singers will drop entire endings of words or consonants to make it sound better but it doesn't mean that what they're singing isn't a word dingle-brain.
 
 Of course the "we" in your song and the "we" in my language may not have the same meaning but it is still a word in my book. Why are we arguing over your hideous babble song anyway?
Because Zardoz likes being a pain in the arse? :p

Why are we arguing over your hideous babble song anyway?

 
 
 Because you can't accept that I'm right.
 
 And it's not really even me, but the singer Eithne Ni Bhraonain (Enya) who stated that the song was Glossia (noise apeing words and language that actually has no meaning...unless you're a submoronic Charismatic Christian brainwashed by apostates into believing magical powers are granted to some people to interpret this nonsense).
 
 So, if you have a problem with the song, contact her. Or even Jckker who initiated this thread.
 All I am is the messenger of truth.
 
 emoticon_xangel

 GIRLS/ Ignorant people who don't know much about languages. It's an emotion based song driven by tone and sound to convey a message and not really what it said.
 Like a Latin Mass for some Catholics. Most participants don't know a damn things that's being said but, some certainly love it for various reasons.
 
 Have you seen Russell Crow's movie Gladiator? This song's in it.
 
 
 Much like what Curt Cobain sung
 "And he likes all our pretty songs
 and he likes to sing along
 and he likes to shoot his gun
 but he know's not what it means,
 he know's not what it means."
 
 And, considering that Enya is pretty successful in her market, many people do love it.
 Some people also like songs in foreign languages.
 
 I myself love the Muslim call to prayer sung in Arabic.
 99 Luftballons is also kinda neat for those from the 80's era.
 ;)

 Well it seems that you're mistaking me with one of those who would never listen to foreign music because "I don't understand it" or "it's silly". Well the truth is, I actually never listen to American music. I never turn on the radio, don't watch MTV or buy CD's. Most of it is pure #### and not worth my hard earned money. 95% of my music is comprised of Indian music, sung in Hindi or possibly even Urdu sometimes. Also, brazilian music is really fantastic. Arabic is probably one of the most beautiful languages I've ever heard, the call to prayer is mesmerizing.
 
 Still, I can't really imagine words like Lof Flesh Lay Flavum sounding good. Am I the only one who thinks those words - oops, it's just babble - sound pleasing to the ear? Say them out loud for christ sake, they're hideous. I'll drop this now

Pssst... Enya is Irish...
 
 She started with Clannad on the Irish Folk circuit before going solo, her first solo album was Watermark. Typically an Enya album has one or two Gaelic songs, one latin song, two or three instrumentals and four or five English songs.
